clinical_study.brief_title: Reduce Radiation Exposure in Fluoroscopic Interventions Evaluation
clinical_study.official_title: REDuce Radiation Exposure in Fluoroscopic INterventions Evaluation (REDEFINE)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether the ControlRad system device when installed in Fluoroscopic (x-ray) machine reduces radiation dose to operators (Doctors and nurses) and to the patient who is undergoing cardiac Catheterization in the cath-lab.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a Prospective, randomized (like a "flip of a coin") single center study evaluating the ControlRad system device when installed - retrofitted on existing C-arms for fluoroscopy (x-ray) will reduce radiation exposure without compromising image quality in the region of interest and overall workflow during cardiac catheterization procedures. Enrollment will be limited to 60 participants scheduled for cardiac catheterization (30 diagnostic catheterization procedures and 30 Interventional procedures). All patients presenting to Beaumont Hospital Royal Oak who are scheduled for cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography in Cath Lab 5 where device is installed will be considered for inclusion in the study. Physicians and staff (20 fellows; 30 attending physicians; and 40 Cath-lab staff) will be invited to participate in the study. For each procedure, 3 staff members will be study subjects: a) the primary operator, b) the secondary operator, c) the nurse/tech who circulates in the room. Different operators and staff may participate in each case depending on cath-lab scheduling. The Primary operator is the physician who usually stands nearest to the C-arm. In most cases in Beaumont this is a Cardiology Fellow. The Secondary operator is the physician who typically stands to the right of the primary operator and in most cases is the attending cardiologist. The Nurse/tech typically circulates in the room and is responsible for monitoring the patient, administering medications and obtaining equipment for the procedure.
The method used to measure radiation dose during the catheterization procedure will be the dosimeter badges. These badges are commercially available and are used in the cath-lab and will be provided free to the participants. Cardiac Catheterization will be performed according to standard guidelines.
Participants will be randomized 1:1 to either cardiac catheterization without ControlRad or cardiac catheterization with the ControlRad system. Participants will be blinded to the randomization.
Once procedure is done,participation also ended and the badges will be removed by the Radiation Safety Officer or research coordinator.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Randomized 1:1 like a flip of a coin, to receive either cardiac catheterization without ControlRad system or cardiac catheterization with the ControlRad system.
study_design_info.masking_description: Participant will be blinded to the arm assigned to; but the investigators, cath lab operators and staff will be informed of the randomized assignment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: During each cardiac catheterization procedure, an average of 30-45 minutes of active radiation
primary_outcome.description: Mean effective radiation dose in millisievert (μSv) to the primary operator at the end of each cardiac catheterization case estimated according to the method of Nikalson using data from a dosimeter at the neck and dosimeter under the lead apron.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During each cardiac catheterization procedure, an average of 30-45 minutes of active radiation
secondary_outcome.description: Mean effective radiation dose (μSv) to the secondary operator at the end of each cardiac catheterization case estimated according to the method of Nikalson using data from a dosimeter at the neck and dosimeter under the lead apron.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During each cardiac catheterization procedure, an average of 30-45 minutes of active radiation
secondary_outcome.description: Mean effective radiation dose (μSv) to the nurse at the end of each cardiac catheterization case estimated according to the method of Nikalson using data from a dosimeter at the neck and dosimeter under the lead apron.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During each cardiac catheterization procedure, an average of 30-45 minutes of active radiation
secondary_outcome.description: Mean radiation dose (μSv) to the patient at the end of each cardiac catheterization case using data from a dosimeter at the neck.

secondary_outcome.measure: Radiation dose in cath lab room #5
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During each cardiac catheterization procedure, an average of 30-45 minutes of active radiation
secondary_outcome.description: Mean radiation dose (μSv) at the end of each case at a standard location on the wall of the catheterization laboratory.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- - Patient
- Scheduled to undergo left heart catheterization with angiography, and/or percutaneous coronary intervention
- Able to provide written informed consent prior to the procedure
- Age ≥18 years
- Physicians and Staff o Able to provide consent for the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- - Patient
- Cardiogenic shock
- Reason for cath procedure is pericardiocentesis
- Inability to provide informed consent
- Pregnant
- Physicians and Staff o Those who are not willing to participate in the study
